The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

Héctor A. Caltenco Department of Health Science and Technology, Center for Sensory Motor Interaction (SMI), Aalborg University, Denmark; Department of Design Sciences, Certec, Lund University, SwedenCorrespondencehector.caltenco@certec.lth.se
View further author information
, Eugen R. Lontis Department of Health Science and Technology, Center for Sensory Motor Interaction (SMI), Aalborg University, Denmark
View further author information
, Bo Bentsen Department of Health Science and Technology, Center for Sensory Motor Interaction (SMI), Aalborg University, Denmark
View further author information
 & Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk Department of Health Science and Technology, Center for Sensory Motor Interaction (SMI), Aalborg University, Denmark

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            • Full Article
            • Figures & data
            • References
            • Citations
            • Metrics
            • Reprints & Permissions
            • PDF

            Abstract

            Intraoral target (typing) and on-screen target (pointing/tracking) selection tasks were performed by 10 participants during 3 consecutive day sessions. Tasks were performed using 2 different intraoral sensor layouts. Reduction of undesired sensor activations while speaking as well as the influence of intraoral temperature variation on the signals of the intraoral interface was investigated. Results showed that intraoral target selection tasks were performed better when the respective sensor was located in the anterior area of the palate, reaching 78 and 16 activations per minute for repetitive and “unordered” sequences, respectively. Virtual target pointing and tracking tasks, of circles of 50, 70, and 100 pixels diameter, showed no significant difference in performance, reaching average pointing throughputs of 0.62 to 0.72 bits per second and relative time on target of 34% to 60%. Speaking tasks caused an average of 10 to 31 involuntary activations per minute in the anterior part of the palate. Intraoral temperature variation between 11.87 °C and 51.37 °C affected the sensor signal baseline in a range from –25.34% to 48.31%. Results from this study provide key design considerations to further increase the efficiency of tongue–computer interfaces for individuals with upper-limb mobility impairments.

            1. INTRODUCTION

            Individuals with severe disabilities may not have the ability to efficiently control standard computer input devices, such as a keyboard or a mouse. They might need a computer interface with a minimum number of physical operations or movements (Allen, 1996). However, for individuals who still have complete mobility and control of complex manipulators (e.g., mouth and eyes), as is the case for individuals with spinal cord injury, a fair number of operations can still be performed using assistive computer interfaces, such as gaze trackers, mouth joysticks, or brain interfaces.

            The performance of assistive computer interfaces is generally significantly lower than that of standard computer input devices. There is no assistive interface that can be considered better than others; the choice of interface may depend on the degree of disability, aesthetics, portability, and the intended use of the computer. Each assistive interface has advantages and disadvantages, and some are designed to emulate keyboard functions or are effective for typing but a poor replacement for the standard mouse, such as speech recognition system. Others are designed to control the mouse pointer and need on-screen keyboards for typing.

            The present study evaluates the functionality of an inductive tongue–computer interface as a keyboard or pointing device for computer control. Intraoral target (typing) and on-screen target (pointing/tracking) selection tasks were performed by 10 participants during three consecutive day sessions. The results provide information for the most optimal location of sensors depending on their function. The present study also helps to assess how undesired activations due to talking can be reduced and how baseline changes due to intraoral temperature changes affect the activation of the sensors.

            2. BACKGROUND

            2.1. Computer Interfaces for Upper-Limb Impairments

            Several interfaces that allow people with severe upper-limb impairments to control a computer have been developed (e.g., head tracking; Fitzgerald, Sposato, Politano, Hetling, & O’Neill, 2009), gaze tracking (Hansen & Pece, 2004), voice recognition systems (R. K. Moore, 2004), chin or mouth joysticks (Bolton & Wytch, 1992), single switch or switch array interfaces (Kim, Tyler, & Beebe, 2005), tongue-operated interfaces (Andreasen Struijk, 2006a; Huo, Wang, & Ghovanloo, 2007), and even brain-controlled interfaces (Li, Nam, Shadden, & Johnson, 2011; Wolpaw, Birbaumer, McFarland, Pfurtscheller, & Vaughan, 2002).

            Brain-controlled interfaces are the only option for individuals with severe motor impairment (e.g., people with locked-in syndrome), but the setup and calibration of these interfaces is complicated and interaction can be slow and tedious. The rest of the aforementioned interfaces are mostly used by individuals with less severe movement impairments, but there is still room for improvement regarding usability of these devices. A common problem with head/gaze trackers and speech recognition systems is that they can accidentally activate commands by a reflex or distraction and could lead to erroneous input (Drewes & Schmidt, 2009). Some other interfaces that require head movements, controlled respiration, or sustained bites present high rates of exertion (Lau & O’Leary, 1993).

            2.2. Tongue-Operated Interfaces

            Although not naturally used for typing or pointing, the tongue can perform sophisticated motor control for vocalization and mastication, has a low rate of perceived exertion, and does not fatigue easily (Lau & O’Leary, 1993), which suggest a potential for computer input for individuals that retain a good motor control of the tongue (Caltenco, Breidegard, Jönsson, & Andreasen Struijk, 2012).

            The tongue tongue-operated switch array (Kim et al., 2005) and the TongueTouch Keypad (Lau & O’Leary, 1993) are intraoral interfaces consisting on five to nine physical buttons that can be pushed with the tongue. The Tongue Drive System (Huo, Wang, & Ghovanloo, 2008) is a headset with magnetic sensors that track the position of a magnetic tracker fixed in the tip of the tongue. The aforementioned tongue-operated interfaces are designed to emulate pointing device functionality and allow keyboard functions only by the use of on-screen keyboards. But regular computer interaction sometimes requires the use of keyboard and mouse functions interchangeably or simultaneously. An interface that emulates both text-input and pointing device functionality can be of great benefit as an assistive device. Directly emulating keyboard devices could improve typing rates if the articulation signal (e.g., tongue movement) is fast and accurate enough to support enough information channels (keys or sensors).

            2.3. Inductive Tongue–Computer Interface

            An inductive tongue–computer interface (ITCI) is being designed at Aalborg University for individuals with tetraplegia (Andreasen Struijk, 2006a). In contrast to the aforementioned tongue–computer interfaces, this interface consists of inductive sensors (coils) that change their inductance if a ferromagnetic material, glued or attached to the tip of the tongue, is placed nearby. A higher resolution (selectivity) than physical buttons in the TongueTouch Keypad is obtained hereby, and is less prone to fatigue, as no effort is needed to “push buttons.” The ITCI is invisible to other people during normal use, which is highly prioritized by assistive device users (sLau & O’Leary, 1993). For more detailed information on the ITCI’s sensors, see Lontis and Andreasen Struijk (2008).

            The ITCI has evolved from nine manually embedded coils (Caltenco, Boudreau, Lontis, Bentsen, & Andreasen Struijk, 2008)—through a set of 24 inductive sensor printed circuit boards (PCBs) embedded in a dental retainer (Lontis & Struijk, 2010)—to a fully integrated wireless system (Struijk et al., 2009). Tongue selectivity in the palatal area has been studied using the manually embedded and PCB versions of the ITCI (Caltenco, Lontis, et al., 2012). The study showed that performance was dependent on the location and distance between the intraoral targets. Performances were faster and more accurate for targets located farther away from the base of the tongue in comparison to posterior and medial targets. However that study (Caltenco, Lontis, et al., 2012) did not address the “typing” or pointing functionality of the device. Moreover, sensors were activated even when the participants were not performing the experiment task and the sensor signals drifted during the experiment sessions.

            The ITCI is today capable of performing text-input and pointing device functions on a personal computer regardless of the operating system and without the need of any software or drivers other than the standard USB keyboard/mouse drivers (Lund et al., 2009). The system can also control wheelchairs (Lund et al., 2010) as well as control a prosthetic hand (Johansen, Popovic, Andreasen Struijk, Sebelius, & Jensen, 2011).

            3. MATERIALS AND METHODS

            3.1. Apparatus

            The ITCI used for this study is based on inductive sensor boards with a total of 24 coils (22 used and two unused) embedded in a palatal plate similar to a dental retainer (Figure 1) and an activation unit, made of biocompatible stainless steel, fixed in the tip of the tongue (Figure 2). When the activation unit nears a sensor, the coil’s inductance is altered according to Faraday’s Law, generating an induced voltage. The activation signal is sampled with a resolution of 1 byte per sensor. Co-polyester plates are used to embed the sensor boards and are molded to individually fit the user’s upper palate and teeth. An insulated copper cable running from the external electronics to the sensor boards carries a battery-driven 50 kHz sine wave current with amplitude of 30 μA.

            3.2. Sensor Layouts

            Two different sensor layouts of the ITCI containing 22 sensors were tested: L1 and L2 (Figure 3). Each layout contained a printed circuit board (PCB) with eight sensors as a tongue mousepad area (TMP), a PCB with 10 sensors as a tongue keypad area (TKP), and two PCBs with two sensors each as tongue function-pad areas (TFP). L1 contained the TMP in the anterior and the TKP in the posterior part of the palatal interface, and L2 vice versa. Both layouts (L1 and L2) contained two TFPs in the most postero-lateral part of the palatal interface (see sensors W-Z in Figure 3).

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors
            Héctor A. Caltenco, Eugen R. Lontis, Bo Bentsen & Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637
            Published online:
            07 March 2014

            FIG. 3. Inner view of the upper palate for the associated characters and mouse directions to each sensor for both layouts. (a) L1: tongue mousepad area (TMP)-anterior, tongue keypad area (TKP)-posterior, and (b) L2: TKP-anterior, TMP-posterior. Note. Both layouts have two tongue function-pad areas (TFPs) in the most postero-lateral areas.

            Display full size

            FIG. 3. Inner view of the upper palate for the associated characters and mouse directions to each sensor for both layouts. (a) L1: tongue mousepad area (TMP)-anterior, tongue keypad area (TKP)-posterior, and (b) L2: TKP-anterior, TMP-posterior. Note. Both layouts have two tongue function-pad areas (TFPs) in the most postero-lateral areas.

            A fuzzy inference system (FIS) was designed to give a proportional relation between the position of the activation unit over the TMP and the “joystick position” output (Caltenco, Lontis, & Andreasen Struijk, 2011). Before the first session, the device was calibrated for each participant, and two FISs for mouse movement (“x” and “y” axis) were trained with 25 activation points within the TMP. Signals from the TMP were treated as an input vector to the FIS, which emulates the position of a joystick and move the pointer.

            3.3. Participants

            Ten able-bodied participants (five per layout; M age = 28 years, SD = 6.18) participated in three consecutive-days training regime. All participants were experienced computer users but had no experience using the ITCI.

            3.4. Experiment Procedure

            The ITCI, customized for each participant, was placed inside the participant’s mouth and secured to the participant’s teeth. A 2 mm. (diameter) × 2 mm. (height) activation unit made of stainless steel type SUS447J1 was glued with Histoacryl 7–8 mm posterior to the participants’ tongue tip (Figure 2). The participants were instructed to sit in front of a 19-in. computer screen with a resolution of 1280 × 1024. The activation signal from the sensor was sent to a computer using RS232 serial. Software running in Matlab R2008a processed the signal, and when the difference exceeded a 15% (for “mouse” functionality) or a 25% (for “key” functionality) threshold, relative to the maximum activation signal for that specific sensor, a character or mouse movement was displayed on the computer screen. In case two or more sensor signals exceeded the threshold, the sensor with the greatest signal amplitude was chosen.

            The training regime consisted of three consecutive-day sessions of intraoral target selection and virtual target pointing /tracking tasks. Each task lasted approximately 30 min/session. At the end of the last session, additional reading and temperature test tasks were performed, which lasted between 5 and 10 min each. A posttest questionnaire was answered at the end of each session.

            3.5. Experiment Tasks

            Intraoral target selection task

            Each sensor of the TKP and TFP is associated with one output text character (Figure 3). The Intraoral target selection tasks required the participant to select a predetermined sequence of targets in the TKP and the TFP parts of the ITCI (Table 1). Once a sensor has been selected, the corresponding character was immediately displayed on the computer screen. The sensor had to be “released” before the next character can be displayed. “Holding” a sensor did not repeatedly output a character.

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors
            Héctor A. Caltenco, Eugen R. Lontis, Bo Bentsen & Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637
            Published online:
            07 March 2014

            TABLE 1 Types of Target Sequences (Sx) and the Number of Times (Repetitions) They Appeared in Each Session

            CSVDisplay Table

            A total of 54 trials were performed in each training session, where participants were instructed to “type” each sequence as fast and as accurately as possible. The sequences for training (Table 1) were either repetitive (S1–S10, S23–S26) or ordered by rows or columns (S11–S22, S27). A “test” sequence (S28) consisted of selecting all 10 sensors of the TKP in an unordered manner and was used to evaluate participants’ performance. The test sequence had no clear sequential order of targets by rows or columns but was always the same sequence as depicted in Table 1.

            Each session consisted of 11 sequence blocks, the first block always comprised two test sequences, following five blocks of training sequences, each followed by a block of two test sequences (2 × S28 → S1–S10 → 2 × S28 → S11–S22 → 2 × S28 → S23–S27 → 2 × S28 → S1–S10 → 2 × S28 → S23–S27 → 2 × S28). As a result the test sequence was performed 12 times, in total, per session. The order of sequence blocks was always the same, but the order of sequences within each training block was randomized. All sequences were cyclic (nonfinite), as can be observed in Table 1, and were displayed for 30 s and interspersed with a 5-s rest period, which was more than enough to finish at least one cycle of a sequence. The total practice time, not counting rest periods, was 27 min. Sequences are based on a previous tongue-selectivity study (Caltenco, Lontis, et al., 2012) and the blocks ordering was chosen to fit the total practice time.

            Target activation time (AT) was measured, in seconds, by the time between the activation of two correct sensors. Accuracy was measured by the rate of activating incorrect sensors and is expressed as error rate (ER), where xcorr and xerr are the number of correct and incorrect activations, respectively: (1)

            These performance indexes were combined into a single performance index: target selection rate (SR), which is calculated as the relation between the accuracy rate and the target activation time: (2)

            As a result, the activation rate between correct sensors is being compensated by the accuracy. Moreover, AT can be approximated as the total time of the trial (30 s) over the total number of correct activations during the trial: (3)

            SR is therefore the target selection rate measuring the “compensated” activations per minute (capm), taking into account the speed (AT) and accuracy (ER) of sensor selection during the trial. Similar performance measures are commonly used for typing and dictation rates measured in characters per second or words per minute (Andreasen Struijk, 2006b; sBates, Donegan, Istance, Hansen, & Räihä, 2007). However, as participants of this study did not correct incorrect characters, performance is compensated with accuracy.

            Virtual target pointing and tracking tasks

            In addition to the intraoral target selection task, participants also performed virtual target pointing and tracking tasks, by controlling the mouse pointer using the sensors on the TMP. There were a total of six trials per session. Each trial lasted 5 min or less (if the trial was completed) and was divided into 16 pointing parts and 16 tracking parts. Circles of 50, 70, and 100 pixels in diameter were displayed randomly in each of the 16 positions uniformly distributed at a distance of 250 pixels from the center of the screen (Figure 4).

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors
            Héctor A. Caltenco, Eugen R. Lontis, Bo Bentsen & Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637
            Published online:
            07 March 2014

            FIG. 4. Example of three consecutive virtual target positions (at random) during the virtual target pointing and tracking tasks. Note. Each virtual target starts at a distance of 250 pixels from the center of the screen (pointing part) and moves toward the center when the mouse pointer is within the target (tracking part). A solid numbered circle marks the initial position of each virtual target. Dashed circles represent the target trajectory when is being tracked. A shaded-continuous circle represents the current target position. Continuous arrow represents the mouse pointer trajectory during the virtual target pointing task and dashed arrow represents the mouse trajectory during the virtual target tracking task.

            Display full size

            FIG. 4. Example of three consecutive virtual target positions (at random) during the virtual target pointing and tracking tasks. Note. Each virtual target starts at a distance of 250 pixels from the center of the screen (pointing part) and moves toward the center when the mouse pointer is within the target (tracking part). A solid numbered circle marks the initial position of each virtual target. Dashed circles represent the target trajectory when is being tracked. A shaded-continuous circle represents the current target position. Continuous arrow represents the mouse pointer trajectory during the virtual target pointing task and dashed arrow represents the mouse trajectory during the virtual target tracking task.

            On the pointing part, the participant had to position the mouse pointer as fast and accurately as possible inside the displayed circle (continuous arrow in Figure 4). Once the pointer was inside the circle, the task would become a tracking task (dashed arrow in Figure 4), where the currently selected target circle (shaded circle in Figure 4) would start moving in a straight line toward the center of the screen at a velocity of 100 pixels per second (dashed circles in Figure 4). The user was then supposed to keep the pointer inside the circle while it moves toward the center of the screen. If the pointer lost track of the circle, the circle would stop moving until the pointer was inside it again. When the target circle reached the center of the screen, it would disappear and a new circle would be displayed in a new position 250 pixels away, and the task would again become a pointing task. This process continued until the entire 16 target circles have been tracked to the center of the screen or 5 min have elapsed.

            The pointing task was evaluated under the ISO 9241-9 standard. Performance measures were obtained for each PCB layout option based on the accuracy and speed of pointing and tracking. For the pointing task, the performance metric used was the pointing throughput (TPP) (Equation 5), quantified in bits/s. The index of difficulty for pointing to a target (ID) (Equation 4) was given by different factors: target width (W), which varied from diameter of 50, 70, and 100 pixels, and distance to the target (D), which was constant (250 pixels) in pointing task. The movement time (MT) is the time it takes the pointer to select the virtual target. (4) (5)

            The tracking task was performed to assess pointer control precision. Pointing throughput does not provide precise information on important pointing-device evaluation aspects such as movement variability, movement offset, and velocity control. The smaller the target, the more precise the pointer control has to be. The performance of the tracking task was assessed by relative time on target (TTT), defined as the relation between the time when the pointer was inside the virtual target (tin) and the total time required by the virtual target to move to its ending position (tin+tout), see Equation 6. If the mouse cursor offset was larger than the virtual target radius, the pointer exited the target and the relative time on target (TTT) would be reduced. (6)

            Speaking task

            A speaking task was performed to detect involuntary activations while talking using the intraoral device. On the last session, after performing the intraoral target selection and virtual target pointing/tracking tasks, the participant was asked to read aloud a 100-word text in English, two consecutive times. The raw data from the sensors was recorded for 30 s each time, to detect undesired activations due to speaking.

            The number of involuntary activations and the movement of the mouse pointer (in pixels) were registered while speaking. In addition, the amplitude and duration of sensor signals were measured.

            Temperature task

            Two temperature sensors were located on the internal side of the palatal plate, one under the posterior PCB and another behind the anterior PCB. The temperature was continuously registered during all the experiment sessions. Sensor inductive properties are temperature dependent; therefore, the signal’s baseline is different when the mouthpiece is inside or outside the mouth, the system must be recalibrated if temperature changes significantly.

            At the end of the third session, after the reading test, the user performed hot and cold (temperature) tests. During the hot-test, the participants were asked to drink hot coffee or tea and repeatedly sipping in 10-s intervals and retaining it each time in the mouth for 1 or 2 s. During the cold-test, the participant was asked to retain an ice cube in the mouth as long as possible. The temperature was registered during the whole task, which lasted 5 min each. One task was followed immediately by the other one, but the order was randomized.

            Maximum and minimum temperatures were recorded for each test. Changes of baseline over time were registered during the tests to build a robust and dynamic baseline adjustment for the ITCI.

            3.6. Summary of Experiment Design

            In summary, a series of analyses of variance (ANOVAs) were undertaken; one for each task. The experiment design for each task was a Layout × (Parameter × Session) mixed factorial design. Layout was a between-subject factor for all tasks and had two levels: L1 and L2. Parameters were different for each task, and repetitions were aggregated into each session for each parameter’s level. Each task had one dependent variable as a performance measure, with the exception of the speaking task, which had two. The levels of the independent and dependent variables are stated in Table 2. Main effect plots are displayed for the last session, as it presents the most significant data due to learning effects. Learning plots display all the repetitions for each session in a consecutive manner.

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            3.7. Statement of Ethics

            An explanation of the experimental protocol and signed consent was obtained prior to the study onset, and the protocol was performed in accordance with the Helsinki declaration (Ethics approval: VN 2005/67).

            4. RESULTS

            4.1. Intraoral Target Selection Task

            The overall target selection rate (SR) was 31 compensated activations per minute (capm). A repeated measures ANOVA revealed a significant main effect on Layout, F(1,8) = 5.319, p < .05. The rate for L2: TKP-anterior was 37 capm, which was 50% higher than the rate of 25 capm observed for L1: TKP-posterior. There was also a significant main effect on experiment session, F(2, 16) = 46.282, p < .001, increasing from 23 to 37 capm across sessions. There was also significant interactions between the sequence group and layout, F(2, 16) = 3.787, p < .05, and between sequence group and session, F(4, 32) = 5.474, p < .005.

            Due to the significant learning effects, it makes sense to report means for the last experiment session and broken down by sequence group and layout (Figure 5). There was a significant main effect on sequence group, F(2, 16) = 42.969, p < .001. Repetitive sequences present (as expected) the highest target selection rate. SR for L2 was 80 capm, which was 63% higher for than 49 capm for L1. SR of ordered sequences for L2 was 36 capm, and for L1 was 26 capm. The test sequence presents the lowest SR (13 capm for L2 and 10 capm for L1). This is expected, as test sequence is cognitively more demanding than other sequences and requires more concentration; it also included all available TKP sensors, and not just a subset of them.

            Fitted learning curves for SR of the test sequence are presented in Figure 6. Learning curves illustrate the learning process of intraoral target selection with the ITCI. The result of the fitted curve is the predicted target selection rate at the nth trial-repetition of the test sequence for each layout.

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            4.2. Virtual Target Pointing/Tracking Tasks

            Pointing task

            The overall pointing throughput (TPP) was 0.60 bits/s. A repeated measures ANOVA revealed that TPP was not significantly different between L1: TMP-anterior (0.58 bits/s) and L2: TMP-posterior (0.61 bits/s), (F1,7 = 0.118, ns). However, there was a significant main effect for target size, F(2, 14) = 30.863, p < .001, and experiment session, F(2, 14) = 14.532, p < .001, increasing from 0.50 to 0.66 bits/s across sessions. There were no significant interaction effects.

            Due to the significant learning effect, but nonsignificant layout effect, it makes sense to report means for the last experiment session broken down by target size but averaged across layouts. For the last training session 50 px targets had a TPP of 0.72 bits/s, which was 22% higher than 0.59 bits/s for 100 px targets (Figure 7).

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637

            Fitted learning curves for TPP are presented in Figure 8. Learning curves illustrate the learning process of virtual target pointing with the ITCI. The result of the fitted curve is the predicted pointing throughput at the nth trial-repetition of all three target sizes averaged and for each layout (L1, L2).

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637

            FIG. 8. Pointing throughput (TPP) for the nth trial over the three experiment sessions for each layout. Note. The fitted learning curve and its equation are shown for each layout.

            Tracking task

            The overall relative time on target (TTT) was 37%. A repeated measures ANOVA revealed that TTT was no significantly different between L1: TMP-anterior (32%) and L2: TMP-posterior (43%), F(1, 7) = 4.480, ns. However, there was a significant main effect for target size, F(2, 14) = 86.915, p < .001, and experiment session, F(2, 14) = 30.236, p < .001, increasing from 29% to 41% across sessions. There was significant interaction effect for session and target size, F(4, 28) = 5.903, p < .005.

            Due to the significant learning effect, but nonsignificant layout effect, it makes sense to report means for the last experiment session broken down by target size but averaged across layouts. On the last training session, in contrast to pointing task, 100px targets had longer TTT (45%) than 50px targets (26%); see Figure 9.

            All authors

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637
            Published online:
            07 March 2014

            FIG. 9. Relative time on target (TTT) for the three target widths for the last experiment session and for each layout. Note. Error bars represent 95% confidence interval. TMP = tongue mousepad area.

            Display full size

            FIG. 9. Relative time on target (TTT) for the three target widths for the last experiment session and for each layout. Note. Error bars represent 95% confidence interval. TMP = tongue mousepad area.

            Fitted learning curves for TTT are presented in Figure 10. Learning curves illustrate the learning process of virtual target tracking with the ITCI. The result of the fitted curve is the predicted relative time on target at the nth trial-repetition of all three target sizes averaged and for each layout (L1, L2).

            4.3. Speaking Task

            The speaking task produced involuntary activations of sensors in the TMP and the TKP. Involuntary activations were produced mainly in the L2: TKP-anterior (Figure 11) and L1: TMP-anterior sensors (Figure 12). A one-way ANOVA revealed that when the TKP was in the anterior area of the palate, there were some character outputs, but no mouse movement, F(1, 8) = 8.224, p < .05. Similarly when the TMP was in the anterior area of the palate, there were some mouse movement, but there were no character outputs, F(1, 8) = 15.307, p < .005.

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637

            07 March 2014

            FIG. 11. Involuntary activation rate (involuntary activations per minute) for each intraoral sensor and for each layout caused by reading aloud. Note. Error bars represent 95% confidence interval. TKP = tongue keypad area.

            FIG. 12. Involuntary mouse movement rate (pixels per second) in the X and Y direction for each layout caused by reading out loud. Note. Error bars represent 95% confidence interval. TMP = tongue mousepad area.

            The speaking task generated on average 31 and 10 involuntary activations per minute in sensors B and E, respectively, F(13, 104) = 6.725, p < .001. Other TKP sensors did not register activations significantly higher than zero (Figure 11). Figure 12 shows that the speaking task generated in average mouse movements of 3.38 and 6.49 px/s in the lateral and vertical directions, respectively, F(1, 8) = 11.481, p < .05. Table 3 shows the amplitudes and duration of involuntary activations. Average involuntary activations had amplitudes not too far above the threshold and with relatively short duration.

            4.4. Temperature Task

            Temperature recordings had high variability because participants were not restricted or encouraged to perform the activities with open or closed mouth. As participants opened the mouth occasionally, the anterior sensor registered lower temperatures than the posterior sensor. Maximum and minimum mean temperatures were registered during the experiment tasks are shown in Table 4.

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors
            Héctor A. Caltenco, Eugen R. Lontis, Bo Bentsen & Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637
            Published online:

            TABLE 4 Registered Temperatures During the Intraoral Target Selection and Virtual Target Pointing/Tracking Tasks for the Anterior and Posterior Temperature Sensors

            CSVDisplay Table

            The mean maximum (hot-test) and minimum (cold-test) temperatures averaged among the participants are shown in Table 5 for each temperature sensor. The minimum registered temperature when having an ice cube in the mouth (cold-test) and while drinking hot beverage (hot-test) varied between 11.87 °C and 51.37 °C.

            The Impact of Function Location on Typing and Pointing Tasks With an Intraoral Tongue–Computer Interface

            All authors
            Héctor A. Caltenco, Eugen R. Lontis, Bo Bentsen & Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk
            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637

            TABLE 5 Registered Temperatures During the Temperature Task for the Anterior and Posterior Temperature Sensors

            CSVDisplay Table

            Figure 13a and 13b shows the temperature observations and Figure 13c and 13d show the ITCI’s sensor-signal variation during the cold-test and hot-test for one of the participants. It could be observed a very clear inverse relation between the temperature and the sensor signals. During the cold-test, on average, a maximum baseline increased by 48.31%, whereas during the hot-test the maximum baseline decreased by 25.34%, relative to the individual coil signal’s activation range (Table 5). Moreover, signal saturated for some of the sensors with temperature increase, but not with temperature decrease.

            https://doi.org/10.1080/10447318.2013.853637
            Published online:

Note. Activation signals for all 22 sensors of the inductive tongue–computer interface are shown during the (c) cold-test and (d) hot-test. Peaks in the signal represent sensor activations caused by swallowing.

            5. DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSION

            This study assessed the ability of 10 able-bodied individuals to perform intraoral target selection and virtual target pointing/tracking tasks with an intraoral computer interface. Participants used the tip of the tongue to activate sensors of an ITCI. The intraoral target selection task assessed the speed and accuracy of selecting sensors in the TKP and the TFP with the activation unit glued in the tongue’s tip; the ITCI outputted a text character associated to the selected sensor. Virtual target pointing and tracking tasks assessed the speed and accuracy of controlling the “mouse-pointer” in a computer screen to point and track moving circular targets of different size.

            The intraoral target selection task had significantly higher performance (SR) when TKP was located in the anterior part of the palate. However, virtual target pointing and tracking tasks showed no significant differences in performance regarding the location of the TMP sensors. This may suggest that, to take advantage of the superior target selection performance in the anterior palatal area, the optimal layout for the ITCI is L2: TKP-anterior & TMP-posterior. These results were obtained for short-term training during 3 consecutive days. Difference between layouts might or might not be significant after long-term training. In fact, for the intraoral target selection tasks, the significance for the effect on layout is only borderline (p < .05) and only five subjects per layout participated in the study. The observed power was 0.29 with an effect size of 0.37. This suggests that a larger number of participants are necessary to correctly assess the layout effects. More participants were not recruited due to the high costs of making custom-fitted ITCIs for each participant. However, within-subject effects have observed power above 0.95 and effect size above 0.75 for all tasks; therefore, more participants are not needed to assess the within-subject effects.

            There was a significant difference in performance when “typing” repetitive, ordered, and test sequences during the intraoral target selection task. The main reason might be that performance is dependent on the distance between intraoral targets (Caltenco, Lontis, et al., 2012). Other reasons could also be cognitive implications, reaction, and searching time. In case of repetitive sequences, mainly the motor processor is involved, whereas for more complex tasks (i.e., test sequences), the perceptual and cognitive processors are also involved (Card, Moran, & Newell, 1983). Moreover, ordered sequence S27 has significantly lower target selection rate than other ordered sequences (S11–S22). Therefore, sensors associated to S27 were excluded in later designs of the ITCI.

            Both, virtual target pointing and tracking tasks are important to assess the functionality of pointing devices. In the pointing task, TPP increases with decreasing target size, whereas in the tracking task, TTP decreases with decreasing target size. This is because TPP for smaller targets had higher ID, but similar MT (Equation 5). On the other hand, the tracking task require more precise pointer control with decreasing target sizes, due that the error tolerance is lower. In contrast to intraoral target selection, virtual target pointing or tracking is not limited by physical capabilities of the tongue but to system capabilities such as mouse pointer control speed, sensitivity, and resolution. In any case, the ITCI seems promising as an alternative (assistive) pointing device.

            The speaking task showed that involuntary activations are mainly produced in the anterior part of the ITCI. It is necessary to reduce involuntary activations, for example, using thresholding and dwell time adjustment techniques. Incrementing the current activation threshold from 25% to, for example, 50% would allow to reduce most of the involuntary activations (Table 3); however, one should be careful not to induce “dead areas” in the coil arrays when incrementing the activation threshold. Another, perhaps better way of reducing involuntary activation is to impose an activation dwell time longer than 200 ms, or introducing a speaking mode, where just some sensors are active. This dwell time is long enough to eliminate most of the involuntary activations while speaking (Table 3) but short enough not to reduce the voluntary interaction speed.

            Providing feedback (e.g., tactile or visual) to the user to locate the position of the activation unit, relative to the sensor arrays is another way to reduce involuntary activations and increase intraoral target selection performance. This might help to increase target selection accuracy by allowing the participant to “correct” the activation unit position before the selection is acknowledged. Another study that investigates the effects of real-time sensor position feedback, using tactile and visual sensory information, in intraoral target selection task was performed (Caltenco, Lontis, Bentsen, & Andreasen Struijk, 2013). The study also investigates involuntary activation reduction, using varying threshold and dwell times.

            During the temperature task, the registered temperature range (Table 5) for the posterior and anterior palatal areas, were similar to other studies in literature (R. J. Moore, Watts, Hood, & Burritt, 1999). These studies have reported oral temperature variation in a 24-hr period between 5.6 °C and 58.5 °C in the anterior oral-area, and between 7.9 °C and 54 °C in the posterior oral-area, with medians of 34.9 °C and 35.6 °C, respectively. Temperature variations can affect the activation signals of the ITCI (Table 5). This could be a problem if the baseline or the minimum or maximum signal values saturate. The saturation of the signal can be problematic because the activation range is reduced. These factors are being considered for designing an automatic baseline and activation threshold adjustment.

            In general, the ITCI is a feasible way for people with severe upper-limb impairments to be used as a text-input and pointing device in a computer system. The results from this study provide key design considerations to further increase the efficiency of tongue–computer interfaces for individuals with upper-limb mobility impairments.

            Additional information

            Author information

            Héctor A. Caltenco

            Héctor A. Caltenco is a research engineer with interest in human–computer interaction, computer interfaces, robotics, rehabilitation technologies and intelligent control systems. He holds a Ph.D. in biomedical engineering from the Center for Sensory-Motor Interaction, Aalborg University, Denmark, and is currently a Researcher at Certec, Lund University, Sweden.

            Eugen R. Lontis

            Eugen R. Lontis is a research engineer with interests in methods for the design of inductive sensors for assistive devices and interfaces. He holds a Ph.D. in biomedical engineering and is currently an associate professor at the Center for Sensory-Motor Interaction, Department of Health Science and Technology at Aalborg University, Denmark.

            Bo Bentsen

            Bo Bentsen graduated in odontology and holds a Ph.D. in oral pain and distraction from Århus University, Denmark. He is an associate professor at the Center for Sensory Motor Interaction, Department of Health Science and Technology, Faculty of Medicine, Aalborg University, Denmark, and owns a private dental clinic in Aalborg, Denmark.

            Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk

            Lotte N. S. Andreasen Struijk is the Tongue Control project manager with an interest in rehabilitation technology, functional electric stimulation, and neural prostheses. She holds a Ph.D. in engineering and is an associate professor at the Center for Sensory-Motor Interaction, Department of Health Science and Technology at Aalborg University, Denmark.
